learning_outcomes.description: Have a broad understanding of mathematical approaches to modelling natural resource and environmental management challenges, involving tools ranging from well-established theory to current advances in statistics and modelling.
Choose, construct and analyse suitable mathematical and statistical models to describe dynamics of biological and environmental systems with sufficient adequacy to use for applied problems.
Clearly present complex mathematical ideas and results.
Use objective approaches to address diverse goals of natural resource management, such as establishing economically and ecologically acceptable harvesting regimes.

assessments.task_description: Problem set on topics covered in weeks 1 - 6 of the lecture.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description: Problem set on topics covered in weeks 6 - 12 of the lectures.

assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.

Quizzes take place during the applied class on Fridays from 12:00 - 12:50 pm and are to be turned in at or before 12:50 pm in class.
assessments.task_description: There are four quizzes in this course, each containing problems based on material covered in lectures, applied classes, and practical sessions. The first three quizzes are not cumulative. The final quiz is cumulative. All quizzes are weighted equally.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
